Reviews.Title: won't turn on in a month
Reviews.Author: seesah "saetoranmin"
Reviews.Content: Purchased at a bestbuy near San Francisco while I was on vacation in September, 2012.Within a month, it won't operate at all. Power button won't work, turning lens won't work.Battery is full, connecting via USB cable is nothing (computer doesn't react).They don't support this product purchased in the US here in Canada.I shouldn't buy Nikon, but something else that has North American support.And it is MADE IN CHINA, no wonder...

Reviews.Title: Disappointing
Reviews.Author: J. Zak
Reviews.Content: Bought the camera to take to Sri Lanka and India. I wanted something compact since we would be on the go. I was disappointed by the resolution of the images. Also the contrast and color range were difficult to work with in photoshop. One of the teens on my trip producedu much better images from a technical stand point with a camera thal cost half of what mine did!!

Reviews.Title: Possibilities
Reviews.Author: Mike Gorecki "spiphoto"
Reviews.Content: I very much enjoy the J1 and came across this link showing images from the Nikon 1 series. I have spend a couple of months using and learning this new system and find it offers excellent quality.[...]

Reviews.Title: Ashton Kutcher was really wrong with the camera.  DON'T BUY IT!
Reviews.Author: Hal W. Levine "Haldoll.com"
Reviews.Content: I generally write good reviews for products on Amazon.  I do all the time, this time the product is Way over priced and the quality is simply AWFUL.  Too bad I can't give it a rating of less than 20.  I gave this camera to my wife in "pink" thinking that she would love it, (and she does love the color and that it is."  You would think that it would at least be a great a point and shoot camera (as it does not allow you to make ANY adjustments less automatic).  The sad part is that it does Automatic extremely poor.  Last night we were at a family party and 60% of the pictures came out blurred and had to be deleted. You cannot adjust aperture settings or focal points.  You can only use the camera for simple pictures.  You have to change the lenses "ALL THE TIME" depending on the picture you are shooting.  You want a portrait shot, change the lens to the  10 -30 and have them stand back a bit because it will blur too close.  Then change to 10 -110 if they stand a little further, you get the idea, what a pain. You would THINK that the cost of this camera would produce at least clean point and shoot but when you have to delete 60% of "STILL" and posed portrait shots, that is ridiculous.  She HATES the camera, Did I say HATES THE CAMERA!  Please, look elsewhere as this camera stinks!

Reviews.Author: Miaski "Mia"
Reviews.Content: Junk!!! Do Not Buy. I have owned this camera for 1 year and 1 month. It just quit working. Seems to be a common problem with this camera. There isn't any power when I push the on/off button. I called Nikon and since it is out of warranty I will have to pay to have it repaired. That's what I get for buying Chinese crap!!!! I have invested a lot in accessories which are now useless because they don't work on any other camera. I will be selling everything and buying anything but a Nikon!!!!!!

Reviews.Author: DAvid
Reviews.Content: Check the internet on nikon j1 lens failure "lens error- please contact a Nikon authorized service center"lot's have people have issues within a year with the lens- without dropping them.once out of warranty they'll charge $145 to repair (a new one is $185!!!)But if you have bought a colored camera, you cannot buy the individual 10-30mm lenses- they only come in kitsSo there you are, stranded with a broken lens which to repair costs almost as much as a new one- only you can't buy a new one because they don't sell themps: if the lens is working- it's a nice camera-but Nikon really put some bad hardware on the market

Reviews.Author: Mark

Reviews.Title: Photos great, Video not so great.
Reviews.Author: Andrian
Reviews.Content: This camera is everything you'd expect from a Nikon. I bought this camera to replace my non-video Nikon DSLR. The picture quality is great but the video not so much. You either have to shoot outside and have the sun shining bright or be recording in a very well lit room if you want to record in the full 1080 on this camera. Any less light and the camera will hardly pick up anything unless you want to reduce quality dramatically. Had I known this I would have just stuck to my original Nikon.

Reviews.Title: Love this camera!
Reviews.Author: Natalie
Reviews.Content: I'm a professional photographer and I got this camera to replace my point-and-shoot with a camera that gives me bit more control over my settings, but I can still use it as a point-and-shoot if I want. So far, I love it! The pictures are as crisp as my Nikon D5000 (if not crisper) and the noise reduction is awesome! I'm not exactly sure how it'll do with moving subjects (I don't have any kids to test it on), but it does take a while to focus, so that's something to keep in mind. It also doesn't seem to have a built in memory system and wouldn't let me take pictures without a memory card (that wasn't a big deal for me, I have 3 extras). But overall, I think it was a good buy for what I wanted.

Reviews.Content: The only thing I don't like about the J1 is that it only has the LCD screen, no other view finder.  If it had a view finder it would completely awesome.  It captures great photos and the lenses are wonderful.

Reviews.Author: James Brower
Reviews.Content: For a product that costs nearly $500, you would think that Nikon would include some onboard memory or a cheap memory card so that you can at least use the thing to take a few pictures.  I guess it's off to find a business that sells memory cards that's open on Christmas morning.Otherwise, it seems to be a well made product so far.  It will keep my wife busy for a few days figuring out all of the settings and features.

I thought it was more of a point and shoot camera but it seems to be a little more than that. I do love the pictures it takes. I love the color. I really do like it but it is hard to figure out. Also, it is bigger than I expected. I sometimes wonder if I wouldn't have been better getting a bigger camera that takes better picture since this one is bigger than I expected.

Reviews.Content: This camera, Nikon 1 J1 is a great little camera. It takes great pictures and is very easy to carry around in my purse.  I would recommend it to anyone who asks.

Reviews.Title: NOT small, NOT inexpensive, Falls WAY short of the hype. WHY pay an extreme premium???
Reviews.Content: I spent Tuesday, November 29, 2011 shooting/comparing a Nikon 1 to my Lumix TS3 and Nikon D5100 and on Wednesday, December 7, 2011 I went to Best Buy down here and bought a red ;) Nikon 1 and an MFT-sensored Lumix GF3 (because the GF3 was on sale for only $399.99) so I could get to the bottom of this whole Nikon 1/mid-sized sensor thing.This review is being written by a very active photographer that has been shooting professional film and digital photo gear for almost 30 years with extensive experience with PNS and Nikon DSLRs who has spent 9 serious days and many snapshooting days with the Nikon 1 and has reviewed the photos at 100% resolution on a calibrated 27" computer monitor. I absolutely appreciate the size and convenience that PNS cameras offer and currently own 9 PNS cameras, 5 35mm SLRs, 4 DSLRs and a Pentax 67. I am definitely NOT some snooty pro that shuns anything non-DSLR or non-pro nor am I some beginner with stars in my eyes or schmuck that doesn't know cameras or what he is talking about. I love my PNS cameras and am intimately familiar with them and came to own them after thorough comparison and experience. I rarely use my pro bodies and opt for my Nikon D5100 or Lumix TS3 nearly all the time.The Nikon 1 body is pretty solid and the lens does have a metal mount. My 1j1 with 10-30mm lens weighs 396.6g without strap and the GF3 weighs 435.7g without strap. My D5100 weighs 830.5g without strap and a Nikon P7100 weighs 395g, a Canon G12 weighs 355g and a Canon SX10 weighs 600g (P7100, G12 and SX10 weight is according to DPReview). The 10-30mm lens zooms rather smoothly for an inexpensive lens, about on par with a Nikon DX 18-55mm VR.The GF3's body is nice and solid but its lens feel is very disappointing. VERY plasticky with a plastic mount and zooming is jumpy particularly going from tele to wide. I can only hope that it will break in and smooth out but I've had modest success with cheap lenses improving over time. But it has a manual focus ring! :) Unfortunately you have to go into the Focus Menu and select Manual Focus before it does anything. :(Generally, the GF3's images tend to be a bit cool and underexposed and the Nikon 1's are a bit warm and overexposed. Contrast is better in the Nikon 1. I believe these issues could be corrected by dialing in some adjustments and then leaving them alone. The GF3's image has better to much better dynamic range than the Nikon 1's when flashing a modestly backlit subject. Dynamic range between the Nikon 1 and Lumix GF3 is similar in strong sunlight.At the pixel level the Nikon 1 is a bit sharper and more contrasty than the Lumix GF3 and textural detail and fine gradation render better on the Nikon 1 than on the Lumix GF3. It has been my experience, these are lens characteristics and likely should speak for the lenses involved (1 Nikkor 10-30mm and Lumix 14-42mm) rather than the sensors. The Nikon 1 also has better high ISO performance than the Lumix GF3, however it is still no match for a DSLR at high ISO. De-magnifying away from pixel level to "fit screen" magnifications of around 35%, sharpness and ISO noise are essentially indistinguishable.It is rather frustrating shooting these cameras in Auto Everything. I can't tell you how hard this is for me to not make constant adjustments. There is no camera in existence that actually does a good job ALL on its own. I'm trying to resist adjusting settings for the sake of this review but when I can't help it, the GF3 is WAY easier to navigate settings, customizations and adjustments. However, the GF3's Manual Exposure mode is terrible as you have to access a menu to change f-stop. What? MENU? It sucks when you have to press a button to switch from shutter to aperture, but to have to access a menu to switch between the two makes Manual Mode pretty much useless on the GF3 unless you are shooting landscapes or other stationary subjects with patience matching or exceeding yours. I don't like the Nikon 1's ergonomics for Manual Mode (or anything else), but at least aperture and shutter are both readily accessible with no menu or button presses.I had an outing in which I compared the 1j1, Lumix GF3, ZS7, TS3 and TS2. I put a tripod plate on each of them and just popped 'em all on and off the tripod and used Program or "Standard Auto." I didn't use Nikon's Auto Scene Mode because it is hopelessly terrible and wasted space in any camera. Nor did I use Lumix's iA (Intelligent Auto) mode because it throws in a bunch of processing and also because it's pretty far from intelligent. Again, wasted space in cameras. It pains me that Lumix wasted a physical button on the GF3 for iA! That could have been a programmable Fn button. But no. It's a wasted button. At least you can program it so that it takes a long push to activate so you don't accidentally wind up in what amounts to "Garbage Mode."The Nikon 1's collapsible lens gets downright frustrating in very little time. The release button must be pressed ALL the way in or release is sketchy or even scary. I have often thought "OH, I've broken it this time!" when I open the lens in a rush. I'm sure many of these lenses will fail because this poor lens lock is destined to break. I consider it a design flaw and Nikon really should do a recall or at the very least comp(limentary) the repair. Many shots are missed in the transition from collapsed to functional states. Leaving the lens in its functional state all the time is scary and it just feels like you're tempting fate by doing so.The Nikon 1's dramatic focus/focus tracking claims are exaggerated and Single Point Single Focus mode still returns the best focus results. It struggles to obtain focus and fails regularly in dim light or darkness even with its AF Assist Illuminator active. I was trying to photograph a friend who was lit by dim ambient street light and a single candle light at an outdoor bistro and the camera simply could not obtain focus. I had to focus on the candle (which was the same distance from the focal plane as her face) and then recompose the shot and then fire. This is a shot a DSLR would have had no trouble with and likely wouldn't have even needed its AF Assist Illuminator for. I also find that when I'm shooting my cats in front of a window screen that the Nikon 1 tends to focus on the screen instead. This is a common theme I am finding with the Nikon 1. It seems to look for linear patterns near the subject if the subject is not well-lit, contrasty or itself of linear pattern. Rather than do its best with your subject, it hunts for something easier to lock onto. A DSLR in Single Point or 3D Continuous Focus mode and not in Live View will track a subject and maintain focus better than a Nikon 1. I don't know if Nikon specifically claims otherwise, but that was my observation.The Nikon 1v1 is a paradox in which the requirement of an external flash would suggest it is targeted at serious photographers though its sole flash "choice" is severely underpowered for an external flash (exactly 2/3 as powerful as a Nikon D5100's internal POP-UP flash). Further perplexing is that neither Nikon 1 has exposure bracketing. The camera's ergonomics leaves WORLDS to be desired by even hobbyists, let alone serious to expert photographers.If you know much about the 1j1 already, let me clear up one of the elephants in the living room; YES, its popped-up flash IS as flimsy and scary-looking as it appears in pictures. It is seriously so bad that I'm scared to use it because one has to baby it pushing its OFF-CENTER mass back into the camera. Make sure you push it down from the left/port side (as seen from rear of camera). If you just nonchalantly pop it back down the way you normally would some other pop-up flash, you realistically could break it off.While we're on the topic of flash, the Lumix GF3 flash's bottom segment can be pulled back (halfway closed) so you can bounce off the ceiling. Kinda neat! Would be really nice if it could hold this position on its own. Your subject will need to be near and/or ISO high to bounce with the internal flash, but it's possible and the results are as would be expected from a bounce. Nice GF1, GF2, GF3 and GX1 perk.The Nikon 1 is a camera that requires just as much attention and adjustment as any other camera to get properly exposed, properly-focused images but it takes more effort to pay that attention and make those adjustments. It has the second-worst ergonomics I've ever used in any camera regardless of price and venturing out of "auto everything all the time" takes too long and is too laborious and often frustrating, particularly with "fleeting moment" photos. If your cat is on his back and super-cute, but you KNOW he's about to roll over, forget it. Just pop the flash (on a 1j1) if necessary, press the button and deal with it in Photoshop. You'll miss the shot if you try to install the flash on a 1v1 and/or change Exposure Mode and/or D-Lighting and/or Focus Mode and/or Picture Control and/or any such item. Making 1 or 2 settings changes on a DSLR can be nearly instantaneous or done within a couple seconds. The same adjustments on a Nikon 1 could take as much as 15-30 seconds. Eons in relative terms and the difference between getting the shot and missing the shot.Frankly, the Nikon 1, particularly the 1v1, is an oversized and vastly overpriced PNS camera whose great parts should be put into a serious compact camera like the Nikon P7100, hence creating the Nikon C7000 instead of being wasted on a fashion camera that doesn't even have any form of grip whatsoever. Its images are very slightly better than a Lumix TS3's and ZS7's, goes back and forth vs. a Lumix GF3 and is NOWHERE near as good as a Nikon D5100's. For anyone in the real world ("real world" = "fill screen" which is roughly 25%-35% monitor magnification, paper prints 12"x18" and smaller, canvas giclee prints 20"x30" and smaller) not literally making really big prints and/or substantial crops on a very regular basis, PNS cameras will yield equally good results. And if you ARE making really big prints and/or substantial crops on a very regular basis, don't kid yourself, a DSLR is DEFINITELY something you should step up to as people this serious about photography will be exponentially better-served with a real camera with dramatically better image quality and real lens and lighting choices.If one MUST get one of these mid-sized sensor mirrorless cameras, I'd suggest the Lumix GX1 as the hands-down mid-sized sensor ergonomics winners (by a huge margin!) with "as good as but different" image quality as a Nikon 1 or I'd suggest the Lumix GF2 and slightly less the GF3 for relatively exceptionally good ergonomics and "as good as but different" image quality as a Nikon 1. Or, based on reviews and NOT my own experience, the Olympus PEN line or Fuji X10. I would recommend against the Sony NEX as it is the only camera I have ever used with worse ergonomics than the Nikon 1. However, the NEX-5n's sensor is worlds better than the Nikon 1's. Particularly intriguing to me is the upcoming Canon G1X (This is NOT a typo. Lumix has the GX1 and Canon has the G1X) with its larger-than-4/3 sensor and fixed 28-112 equivalent f/2.8-5.8 lens.I would still recommend against this type of camera for ANYONE. These cameras barely if at all deliver on the promise of more portability than a DSLR and the Nikon 1's claim of DSLR-caliber images is a blatant lie and falls WAY short of such a lofty statement. Their images are LITERALLY virtually indistinguishable in the real world from any quality PNS camera. And their ergonomics are essentially identical to the average PNS. In the case of the Nikon 1 and Sony NEX, ergonomics are WORSE than the average PNS.I really wanted the Nikon 1 to be "the photographer's camera when going light." It is truly extremely far away from that! If you're a Leicaphile looking for a cool toy, you're gonna be REAL disappointed with the Nikon 1.Nikon threw a fishing lure out there to appeal to iPhone users/fashionistas who are more gadget-fashion-conscious and menu-driven and PNS shooters BY FAR than to real photographers or those who genuinely are concerned with GETTING the shot or image quality. Even iPhone users/fashionistas balked at the ridiculous price for a toy camera that is actually available, I kid you not, in pink. Hence, the immediately-slashed prices.If you need portability, get a pocketable PNS like a Lumix TS3 or Nikon AW100, both waterproof and shockproof with non-extending lenses. Or for non-tough cameras with extending lenses; a Lumix ZS7 or ZS10 or Nikon S8200 or S9100 or Canon S95 or S100.I just got a Canon S100 and I have to tell you, it's been a little while since I've had such a "WOW" experience in cameras. I HIGHLY suggest you check one out. Reviews out there are mixed on it but I don't care about the reviews. I have one (and its predecessor the S95) and I've been shooting it. It produces MUCH better image quality than the already very good S95. The S100's image feel is similar to the Nikon 1's in that it is very saturated and rich. I call this "juicy." Its dynamic range is fantastic and the S100 has easily and instantly positioned itself as my favorite PNS camera to date and I plan on selling off most of my PNS cameras now. All I need for non-DSLR cameras now are my Canon S100 and Lumix TS3. In all honesty, the S100's image feel is arguably my favorite of ANY camera. Yes, including my DSLRs. Now, I'm not saying that at the pixel level the S100 can hold up vs. DSLRs for grain/noise, edge detail or other pedantic idiosyncrasies that will never matter in a shot not being turned into a billboard. It can't. But for real life prints (16x20 and maybe larger) and easily fill-screen magnifications, it is a very lush looking image that I find EXTREMELY satisfying.I would take a Canon S100 over a Nikon 1 any day. I like its image feel more, its ergonomics are WORLDS better and it is a VERY small and light camera that can EASILY fit in my jeans front pocket and it has a 24-120mm F2.0-5.9 lens that is super colorful, contrasty and quite sharp, though 24mm has lots of distortion.Visit Amazon's Canon S100 page and view the customer images.http://www.amazon.com/gp/customer-media/product-gallery/B005MTME3U/ref=cm_ciu_pdp_images_allTons of beautiful juicy images. And easily-shot too. Check the Nikon 1 J1's page on Amazon.http://www.amazon.com/gp/customer-media/product-gallery/B005OGQXJW/ref=cm_ciu_pdp_images_allThere are only 2 images; 1 of a customer's J1 captioned that it can't take a picture of itself and one of a warehouse ceiling stating the camera has trouble focusing. Amazon's V1 page has not a single customer image...I'm calling it right here, right now. The Canon S100 is THE smaller-than-DSLR camera to own. Period. And compared to a Nikon 1, it's dirt cheap. That's my take. Now if only they would paint the S100 in Nikon 1 J1 candy red... :)If you want a rangefinder camera that's substantially more portable than a DSLR and pocketable in loose pockets (i.e. slacks, but not jeans) or a modest purse, get a Nikon P7100 or Canon G12. Both the P7100 and G12 are lighter, more compact, have faster lenses with more to dramatically more zoom range, built-in flash and VASTLY (I cannot stress this enough; VASTLY) superior ergonomics.The Nikon 1, despite the potential of its good sensor, fast and good image processing and superb Live View simply can't materialize its potential into a camera that consistently captures exceptional images because of truly egregiously flawed physical ergonomic and menu design that so completely gets in the way of making necessary adjustments that many pictures simply are missed. Its poor focusing in anything other than bright light costs further shots still and at night it is almost completely unusable even in Single Point Single Focus with AF Assist Illuminator active. It is either a camera that must be relegated to situations where time can be spent to set up a shot (like in a studio or with patient subjects/landscapes) or as an auto everything all the time camera. There are tons of better cameras for the former situation at the same price or less and it is not very good in the latter situation and is no better than cameras that cost a fraction of its price there.I'm sure there will be those who love the Nikon 1 and I'm happy for everyone who finds something they love. But I don't love the Nikon 1. I don't even like it. To me, it really isn't worth owning at any price. Even if I was given one for free, I would never use it.I am rating this camera only 2 stars because of its price. There is no escaping the fact that it is a very oversized PNS camera with slow to very slow lens(es) and very limited zoom range except for its really slow $750 10-100mm f/4.5-5.6 video lens. As such, it should cost no more than $300-$350. Given its terrible ergonomics, it shouldn't cost more than $300. At $300, I would give it 3 stars simply because given the right circumstances it CAN produce very nice images. Its ergonomics keep it from ever earning more than 3 stars even if was given away for free. No matter what, it is a camera I would never choose to use and actually dreaded using it while doing this review because I wanted to take pictures... and not wrestle with menus and calculate how the camera would respond to certain situations and what settings that would require to get the shot, in which time the shot had vanished.I have since returned the Nikon 1 and the only thing I miss is the gorgeous red paint. And I'm not kidding. The ONLY thing I miss is the color of the paint.

Reviews.Title: Do NOT buy!
Reviews.Author: Erin Snyder
Reviews.Content: We bought this camera in March of 2012. Worked fine until August of that same year. We were on a trip and it just died. Super annoying and we had to send it in to get it fixed. Then less than a year later after getting it fixed, it died AGAIN! Now it's out of the warranty to be able to get it fixed. $600 down the drain.  Just called customer service and they won't do anything. Thanks Nikon. Super disappointed and I feel like I got taken.

Reviews.Title: It's decent but not worth the money
Reviews.Author: Nick
Reviews.Content: Video quality is amazing, however photo quality is so-so.  Sometimes it will really nail it and get a good picture, but more often than not you get a picture that isn't impressive at all.

Reviews.Title: Nikon j1
Reviews.Author: Javi T
Reviews.Content: Nikon j1 camera works well. They did never made it clear this item was refurbished. As far as the camera it does work well and overall happy with it. 8/10 on the product 5/10 on description

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: Camera Fan
Reviews.Content: I love this camera and both lenses! I did have to learn about the settings on the camera since I have only used a point and shoot camera in the past. The photos are super crisp, once you know which settings NOT to use. I love the auto focus. I have had it for almost a month, and I look for reasons to take photos. It is not as simple as a point and shoot, but once you learn about the settings, it is simple. To take great photos.

Reviews.Title: JI
Reviews.Author: Alicia Liang
Reviews.Content: I love that pink color!!!!!! It's so fantasy!!! The camera is very good and the price is a lot cheaper than in china.

Reviews.Title: happy costumer
Reviews.Author: Adriana Benavides
Reviews.Content: its perfect! i just have to learn how to use it! it arrived on time with no problem and fine

Reviews.Title: Camera
Reviews.Author: Cat
Reviews.Content: The nixon camera is great. We Love it. We love it so much we went out and bought another zoom lens for it. Now we can take pictures up close or very far way.

Reviews.Title: Very nice camera and very easy to use.
Reviews.Author: Robert Magruder
Reviews.Content: We used it over Christmas and got some very good pictures from it.  It was very easy to use. I like it a lot.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Dr. Rainer Burkhardt
Reviews.Content: Well, I've seen the Ashton Kutcher commercial on TV advertizing the rapid speed that makes the Nikon 1 J1 a great camera and the relatively small form factor.The first is true, the latter .. not really.I love this camera for this mode that shoots 4 images in a row. Also, the 30-110mm Lenses are a very good alternative to my iPhone's camera. The 10-30mm on the other hand does not give me a whole bunch of opportunities that I would have missed otherwise .. and it's not really as slim as I thought after watching the TV ad. Since I am not that type of guy who wants to advertise to the world that "the photo pro" is here (not only because I'm not) I would have liked it as good as it is, but slimmer. I am probably still using my iPhone a lot more than this fancy Nikon 1 J1 here, because .. I am not sure if I will always have it with me and I got kind of used to it not to write down or memorize where exactly I took a snapshot and to the comfort of not having to add the location once it's imported into iPhoto - sounds like I sort of expected some GPS or something alike .. am I spoiled or what?

Reviews.Title: Hard to use and expensive
Reviews.Author: L. Hurley
Reviews.Content: I have a leica point & shoot D-Lux 3 and a Nikon D300 SLR....we bought the J1 for our daughter as an alternative to an SLR....turns out its an expensive camera that's harder to use than both an SLR which she wanted and a point & shoot which she needed....Trying to figure out how to unlock and focus the lens ring each time is maddening... The design is very cool, the images look good (not spectacular) but for the money and the difficulty in using it, you can find an easier point & shoot for less money with the same quality and more durability, or you can buy an SLR and blow the quality away. After trying to use the J1 twice and finding it ridiculously hard, our daughter went back to her I-phone 4S which should be a wake up call to camera makers world wide....in order to make any of us use something other than our 8MB phones, you have to offer something vastly superior and easy to maneuver...the J1 has the looks but doesn't deliver...If you buy this camera, save the receipt.

Reviews.Title: This Camera stopped working after 35 days...
Reviews.Author: Robin Beadle
Reviews.Content: this camera broke a week ago - just a few days after 30 day Amazon return warranty. Authorized Nikon Repair in Chicago Illinois says they have to take the camera apart and find out whats wrong - some type of switch/electrical issue.If there is anything I can do to return the camera in exchange for a new one - and Amazon can follow up on 1 year warranty, it would be greatly appreciated.

Reviews.Title: does not work
Reviews.Author: Maguí
Reviews.Content: The battery shows ta is fully charged but when put in camera does not even turn on. Started using it after the period to returned it and finded out didn't work . Not at all nice

Reviews.Title: Awesome Camera
Reviews.Author: Ann "Wallet Lady"
Reviews.Content: We bought this camera for product images. My photographer says "Awesome camera, easy to use, great features. Makes going to work a pleasure." What more can I say?

Reviews.Title: Does not work properly
Reviews.Author: sandralm39
Reviews.Content: For such an expensive item, I have not been happy with the results. Now it locks and does not work properly.

Reviews.Title: camera is great.
Reviews.Author: iluvlabs
Reviews.Content: the camera is awesome.  i upgraded from a point and shoot to this so i could capture my kids pictures more quickly.  my only disappointment is that the case shown in the picture is nothing like the case i received.  i expected a nikon case and received a vinyl bag and an already opened sd card.  love the camera, not so much the case.

Reviews.Title: i love this camera
Reviews.Author: feier guo
Reviews.Content: i like this pinky camera! good-looking and great effect. and it has two lesson , easy for u to get pic for people and view.

Reviews.Title: Buen Producto
Reviews.Author: Emiliano del Solar
Reviews.Content: La Nikon j1 es una súper maquina, muy buenas fotos toma. Buena velocidad, buenas funciones, ahora estoy comprando el lente 30-110mm.  Me falta terminar de aprender a usarla.

Reviews.Title: Nikon J1
Reviews.Author: Robert
Reviews.Content: Great product:  The two lenses are a great option.  One for around the house/town and the other for sporting events or school plays if you want closeup's.  The "User's Manual sucks if you are not a professional photo person!!!  Have ordered the "For Dmmies booklet", hope it is worth it.

Reviews.Title: Galaxy S4 Better Photos
Reviews.Author: S. M. Woods
Reviews.Content: You would be better off buying a true Digital SLR for close to the same price. My S4 phone takes as good if not better photos for general day to day.  S4 is 13mp this is 10mp, and you then have internet t upload.Mac with mountain lion will not recognize the camera.

Reviews.Title: nikon 1 J1
Reviews.Author: Oscar "Theog187"
Reviews.Content: This is very good camera takes good pictures and the video this is my first camera and i love it .

Reviews.Title: Nikon 1 J1 horrible
Reviews.Author: Cyndy
Reviews.Content: I am totally unsatisfied with this Nikon camera.  We took approximately 50 photos on it and the battery died.  Then after charging it and downloading the pictures to the computer, it has stopped working completely.  How do I get my money back?

Reviews.Title: Almost....
Reviews.Author: Peter Laszlo
Reviews.Content: Well... It was a christmas present for my wife. She opened up the box and it turned out that the camera is white instead of red. Both of us were disappointed...

Reviews.Title: Nicon 1 J1
Reviews.Author: Frances E. Jones
Reviews.Content: I have not had to opportunity to use the camera on a trip so far, but it is exactly what I wanted and expected.

Reviews.Title: Nikon N1 J1
Reviews.Author: onapap1
Reviews.Content: I was so hyped to buy this camera. I had a Coolpix S8000 that took beautiful photos for a point and shoot. I cannot get a photo with the N1 that compares to even the worst I have taken previously. I have had it two months. The resolution is bad with either the zoom or the telephoto lens. I was wanting to get the wide angle lens but not unless I can get help with this. Every picture is extremely noisy and grainy appearing. I am probably going back to where I purchased it and see if I can get help.

Reviews.Title: Not satisfied with my purchase Nikon J1
Reviews.Author: mazoon
Reviews.Content: I have purchased a nikon J1 few months ago and I am extremely unsatisfied with my purchase.I have received a defected product the lens and the flash of the camera weren't working and I had to send it back right before my holiday, so it was useless.After they fixed it which took nearly 3 weeks, my camera stopped working all of a sudden and again right before my holiday therefore, its useless again.

Reviews.Title: Beware!  VERY POOR low light performance.
Reviews.Author: Brad M. Cassagne "Computer Buff"
Reviews.Content: I tried this camera in the store for a while before deciding on the Sony NEX-5.  I must say the light gathering of the Nikon was just horrible.  I was in a very well lit store and the camera on auto mode was defaulting to ISO 3200 with a 1/15 shutter speed!!!!  This is just horrible.  There was no filter on the lens.  Zooming on the shots afterwards revealed serious noise and some blur, as you would expect.  The Sony took the same picture with 200 ISO and 1/60 shutter speed!!  This almost makes me think the Nikon was defective except the exposure level looked just fine.  I was going to buy this camera and then upgrade the body later on, maybe to the V1, but I realized this would not do.  I like the size of the Nikon, but the Sony is small enough.  I know the Sony has a bigger and better sensor, but WOW, really?  The Nikon J1 is FAR too expensive for this level of performance.

Reviews.Title: totally ruined our trip!
Reviews.Author: Zehua Zhou
Reviews.Content: We bought this camera and it was broken at the time we opened the package. We exchanged for another one before our four day trip to Las Vegas. It broke down on our last day. It damaged the SD card too. Our data is all lost. I hate this camera!

Reviews.Title: Not as good as expected
Reviews.Author: Seysha Ontiveros
Reviews.Content: Bought as a gift for my daughter who saw the commercials and had to have it.  But as we began to use it we found that it was not as good quality as we expected for the price  we paid. The flash seemed flimsy and the zoom took very pixilated pictures. Not good quality for a Nokia

Reviews.Title: Please, do not buy!!!  Brand new camera does not even work out right out of the the box!
Reviews.Author: Brian G
Reviews.Content: If you are looking for a camera, please look elsewhere.  I should have listened to the poor reviews on Amazon but did not.  Electronics should be treated as if you are buying a hotel room.  A hotel with a handful of reviews stating poor service/bed bugs/unclean should be avoided, even if there are plenty of good reviews for the hotel. The same goes for electronics.I work outside the USA and bought this camera for a trip to Paris at the end of the month.  I wanted to get some better shots compared to what my point and shoot gives me so I picked this up as it looked like a decent camera at a good price.  Upon receiving it I opened the camera up and charged the battery.  Popped in the charged battery and nothing.  No error message, no flicker of light nothing.  I am now forced to return this to Amazon (and hope I get my refund) since I cannot send it to Nokia technicians (customer service is worthless).  I am also stuck with a leather case and carrying bag since the outer cases/packaging for these have been thrown away before I figured out the camera was defective.Thanks to the inferiority of this camera, I am now going to be stuck trying to buy an SLR camera in Dubai, where everything is overpriced, prior to flying out to Paris.  Thanks to everyone involved for the big let down!  Remember, always listen to the 1 star reviews when looking to make your final purchase, especially on an item over $250!!!

Reviews.Title: deceived
Reviews.Author: Matthew
Reviews.Content: deceived about everything but the camera, i wish i knew prior because i would have not have gotten this product from this particular seller, apart from the shipping that did not come on time. And the product works fine, the so called white case which is not listed under the product description but under the title just as a "case(white)" was not even white or even the leather case as shown. the Extreme 8 scan disk memory card was a cheaper one then shown also. please don't buy from this seller. If i had known prior i would have bought everything separate as planned, but saw this package with everything i wanted. so lied to, i would have rather spent the extra 80 on the all the stuff i want. the cameras fine an the only thing giving the seller the 2 stars. TWO BIG FST THUMBS DOWN!!!!!!!!!!! suck it

Reviews.Title: Crap
Reviews.Author: M. BROOKS
Reviews.Content: Bought this and all lenses offered straight from Nikon and WOW what a rip off. Only takes a descent picture once out of every 7-10 tries. We had a new baby on the way and our Canon died right before the due date so we ordered the Nikon. NEVER AGAIN!! Every picture we have of our first night with our new addition is blurry, glared, and/or too dark to see. Luckily our midwife had a friend that happens to be an infant/toddler photographer that she called in a favor to. Amy shows up with her gear and saved the night. She played with the Nikon for an hour and said we just purchased a very expensive paper weight

Reviews.Title: Very good item but a little big
Reviews.Author: jcmarrou
Reviews.Content: It is a good camera. The pictures are excelent and the videos are perfect. The only issue is that I can't keep it in my pocket because it is a little bigger than the ones I had before.

Reviews.Title: A Niche Camera for the Confused Wealthy
Reviews.Author: J. S. Cooper "Conspicuous Consumer"
Reviews.Content: I guess I was thinking this could be a Leica replacement without the outrageous price. But it doesn't seem to work. Fast lenses that aren't really fast. Colors lost by a diminutive sensor. And the need to divine the cryptic actions with each setting, and the tedium to set them.I ordered the V1. It failed to recognize the card on the 2nd use. And for some reason programs like Lightroom don't like NEF Anymore.So back it went.I think I'd rather spend less and get something that will fill the need for a top shot without lugging out the big guns.Not a pleasant purchase. Even without the defect, doesn't seem to have a well designed purpose

Reviews.Title: Ended up returning it.  Not for the clumsy!
Reviews.Author: B. Espiritu
Reviews.Content: When I first saw this camera, I was in awe and was so excited to get it.  When I got it, however, it really looked nice.  But being the clumsy guy that I am, I knew I'm going to end up dropping it when I switch lenses.  It's really a great camera, but I wanted to write this review for anyone who thinks it's like a point-and-shoot camera.  I opted to buy the Nikon AW100, which is shock-proof and water-proof (to 10 meters), and had much more fun using it.

Reviews.Title: Bigger than it appears
Reviews.Author: Tametha morrow
Reviews.Content: In the photo and on the commerical it appears you can use the camera without the lens but you  can not. The lens is bigger than the camera. So if you are looking for a small compact camers, this is not the one.

Reviews.Title: Don't bother, it is not a Canon camera!
Reviews.Author: dark life "dunkelleben"
Reviews.Content: After almost 3 months I realized that this camera wasn't Canon so tried to return it but they said no...always check the brand name before buying anything!
